entry.title: Re: Sap_payslip_de_o Hrforms payslip custom/copied infone...
entry.content:
Here are few check lists :
1) You may not have linked the z infonet to the conversion rule
Navigate to Form Attributes → Signature Conversion (from HRFORMS)
2) Check the customizing table, V_512W_D (sm30) 
Against WageType, evaluation class should be 03
for DE (German) this class controls whether a wage type is considered as a deductible or earning
Wage type concepts - SAP Community
3) You can further debug the form using HRFORMS_TRACE, to check how the wage type is getting interpreted
4) Check the feature P0002 for any German(DE) specific settings
Hope this helps, Cheers!

entry.title: Automatic Quota Payout on Termination
entry.content:
We are a Canadian public sector company, and in Time Evaluation we have automated the Quota Payout on Termination process.

Currently, when an employee terminates while on an inactive LOA, Time Evaluation generates a specific set of wage types on the last active day, which payroll successfully pays out if the termination occurs during the inactive LOA. Functionally, everything works fine—the system generates the payout hours and payroll processes the payment correctly.

Previously, we used IT0416, which updated IT2006 after termination, ensuring the hours were deducted once payroll paid them. However, with the new automation, the issue we are facing is that IT2006 is not being updated. After termination, the employee’s quota balance still shows hours remaining in IT2006. This creates problems in two cases:

  • When the employee is rehired, or

  • When payroll runs through IT0003.

Currently, we are handling this manually using IT2013 corrections, but we are looking for a solution where the system automatically updates the IT2006 deduction fields once payroll has paid out the quota hours.

Do you guys have any suggestions or best practices to resolve this issue so that IT2006 is updated automatically in line with the payout?

Thanks

entry.title: “Business Excellence with SAP’s New Clean Core Extensibility Levels: Why, What and How”
entry.content:
1. Introduction:

SAP provides pre-delivered content to run your business. A Clean Core approach means keeping Cloud ERP systems up-to-date, free from unnecessary customizations, and aligned with industry best practices. This gives the benefits of driving innovation-readiness, ensuring seamless future upgrades and reducing technical debt.

1.1 Key guiding principles of a Clean Core

There are five essential guiding principles that contribute to an efficient and sustainable Cloud ERP system:

  1. Processes – Streamlining end-to-end (E2E) business workflows for efficiency.
  2. Integration – Ensuring seamless communication between extensions and core enterprise solutions.
  3. Extensibility – Extending standard software functionality to meet unique organizational needs.
  4. Data – Managing configuration, master, and transactional data effectively.
  5. Operations – Managing infrastructure, upgrades, system monitoring, and maintenance.

In this article, we will focus on the “Extensibility” guiding principle.

To support business differentiation while maintaining a Clean Core, organizations can adopt various extensibility models.  A clean core strategy doesn't mean to exclude extensibility entirely, the crucial part is understanding the appropriate way to implement the extensions.  You can create extensions using SAP Build via “Side-by-side” extensibility (loosely coupled) on BTP (including AI-enhanced pro-code and low-code tools) or through “S/4 HANA On-stack” extensibility (tightly coupled).

2. WHY New Clean Core Extensibility Levels:

SAP has refined its clean core model, evolving from the former three-tier structure to a more detailed four-level concept (A, B, C, and D). Instead of a simple “clean vs. not clean” classification. These levels show how closely your custom extensions align with clean core principles.

This evolution provides greater clarity for extension decisions and simplifies qualification criteria, giving organizations a more practical way to balance innovation with long-term sustainability. It’s about making smarter, future-proof extensibility choices while ensuring business differentiation doesn’t come at the cost of technical debt.

Here’s what it means in practice:

  1. Smarter, future-proof choices – Enable meaningful business differentiation without slowing down with legacy overhead.
  2. Clean, scalable extensions – Build on SAP BTP, ABAP Cloud, and SAP Build—all supported by Joule, SAP’s AI copilot.
  3. Progress you can measure – Monitor and track clean core adoption with tools like the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard and ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC). The dashboards will be updated and reflect the new levels.

3. WHAT are the new clean core extensibility Levels:

Before exploring the new clean core extensibility levels are, it is important to understand what an API is—because most of these levels are closely tied to APIs.

  • An API (Application Programming Interface) is essentially a defined set of rules, protocols, and interfaces that allows one software application to communicate with another.
  • In simple terms, an API acts like a bridge. It lets developers access specific functions, data, or services of a system without needing to dive into, or modify, the underlying code.

There are four extensibility levels from the cleanest form of extensions to not clean extensions.

Level A – The cleanest form of custom extensions. These are built either directly on-stack with the ABAP Cloud development model or side-by-side on SAP BTP using SAP Build, whether through ABAP Cloud, CAP, or low-code/no-code tools. Represents highest standard in SAP extensibility, offering future-ready solutions with maximum upgrade stability by utilizing released API’s and extension points.

Level B –Extensions that follow SAP’s best practices for classic ABAP development and use only officially provided SAP APIs and frameworks. These extensions can be used only if the requirements cannot be fulfilled by set of released APIs (Level A). These include wide range of legacy APIs, user exits, BadIs and established frameworks like SAP GUI and ABAP list viewer grid.

Level C – Extensions at Level C involve the use of SAP internal objects that are not classified or intended for customer use. These objects are neither officially released, recommended, nor cloud-ready, and they fall outside SAP’s formal support scope. However, with the introduction of the new changelog for SAP objects (currently in work and will become later available), customers can proactively analyze and plan for potential upgrade impacts when Level C objects are affected by incompatible changes. For this reason, Level C extensions are considered conditionally clean.

Level D – Classified as not clean core. This level includes extensions that don’t follow SAP’s guidelines, such as system modifications, reliance on non-recommended SAP objects, or unsupported techniques like implicit enhancements.

Below table explains the differences in each level for comparison.

For detailed guidance on frameworks, technologies and development patterns in the context of clean core extensibility, please refer to SAP Note: 3578329.

4. HOW to find SAP extensibility objects classification by levels:

The “SAP Business Accelerator Hub” and “Cloudification Repository (API Viewer)” are the central tools to classify objects by clean core level. It shows which objects are:

  • Released APIs (Level A)
  • Classic APIs (Level B)
  • No APIs (Level D)
  • Internal Objects (Level C – default when not classified as A, B and D)

The SAP API Business Hub is SAP’s central catalog of APIs, integration content, and business services. All the APIs are classified as Level A. Remote APIs are for consumption in BTP and local APIs are for consumption in “On-stack extensibility”.

The Cloudification Repository Viewer is an interactive tool designed to help developers explore API details for “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public” and “SAP S/4HANA Private Edition” for on-stack extensions.

Links:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (Doesn’t include Classic APIs)
  • SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition (Classic API’s)

In this article, I will be demonstrating the usage of “S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition”.

4.1 Extension Level A

The cleanest form of custom extensions. These are built either directly on-stack with the ABAP Cloud development model or side-by-side on SAP BTP using SAP Build, whether through ABAP Cloud, CAP, or low-code/no-code tools. You can find the released API’s at SAP Business Accelerator Hub. If you are a developer, you can find the released API’s directly in the IDE (Integrated Development Environment).

 Alternatively, for “SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition" you can follow the below steps.

Detailed Steps:

1. Go to S/4 HANA Cloud ERP Private  (Doesn’t include Classic APIs)
2. Click “Show Filter Bar”

3. Choose “Released” under State drop down.

4. You have different options to filter results based on “Object type”, “Software Component” and “Application Component”

5. You can also search for objects (Example of search results for “purchase_order”)

4.2 Extension Level B – Classics APIs:

Extensions that follow SAP’s best practices for classic ABAP development and use only officially provided SAP APIs and frameworks. These extensions can be used only if the requirements cannot be fulfilled by set of released APIs (Level A). These include wide range of legacy APIs, user exits, BadIs and established frameworks like SAP GUI and ABAP list viewer grid.

Detailed Steps on finding the Classic API’s:

  1. Go to S/4 HANA Cloud Provide Edition (Classic API’s)
  2. Click “Show Filter Bar”

3. Choose “Classic API” in the state 

4. You can choose filter criteria as needed

5. You can also search for objects (Example of search results for “sales”)

4.3 Extension Level C – Conditionally Clean

Extensions at Level C involve the use of SAP internal objects that are not classified or intended for customer use. These objects are neither officially released, recommended, nor cloud-ready, and they fall outside SAP’s formal support scope. However, with the introduction of the new changelog for SAP objects (currently in work and will become later available), customers can proactively analyze and plan for potential upgrade impacts when Level C objects are affected by incompatible changes. For this reason, Level C extensions are considered conditionally clean.

  • You can find objects in Level A (Released APIs), Level B (Classical APIs) and Level D (No APIs).

Level C refers to all internal SAP objects that are neither “Released APIs,” “Classical APIs,” nor “APIs” at all. Since they are internal objects, no official list exists.

4.4 Extension Level C – Conditionally Clean

Classified as not clean core. This level includes extensions that doesn’t follow SAP’s guidelines, such as system modifications, reliance on non-recommended SAP objects, or unsupported techniques like implicit enhancements.

Detailed Steps on finding objects which are “Not APIs” classified as “No APIs”

  1. Go to S/4 HANA Cloud Provide Edition (Classic API’s)
  2. Click “Show Filter Bar

3. Choose “No API” in State

4. Results with “No API” are displayed

5. Successor information is available for some of the objects.

5. Summary:
With this evolved model, SAP is giving organizations a smarter playbook for extension decisions. By aligning with clean core principles on a clear scale (Levels A, B, C and D), businesses can innovate faster, keep their systems future-ready, and reduce technical debt—while still getting the flexibility they need today.

entry.title: Changing materials without losing history
entry.content:
I am trying to figure out the best way to handle this situation. My company is a recycling company. Using a process order, we take widgets, disassemble them and separate them into different parts, each different part being a unique Semi Finished Good. Once they are separated, the parts are tested for their quality and then moved into a graded Finished Good material. What is the best way to handle the process for grading?

We are considering doing a material to material transfer to take the SFG to the Graded FG. But the problem with that is that we lose the batch number, the inspection results and traceability to the original widgets. We are also looking into using a rework process order, but that would be a lot more work for the quality team to manage. But in this case, we could copy the inspection results to the new inspection lot (Inspection Results are important for the Certificate of Analysis).

Does anyone have any recommendations on the best way? Is there another way I haven’t considered?

 

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: All you need to know about SAP Cloud Availability
entry.content:
Being aware of your cloud system status and upcoming events taking place is a requirement to current businesses setup. SAP ensures that you have a seamless visibility about your cloud solutions by launching the SAP Cloud Availability application. 

 
But you might wonder, how can I access this feature? Well, let me guide you through this process. 

 
SAP Cloud Availability in SAP for Me 

The SAP Cloud Availability application is part of SAP for Me, which is currently the main entry point for support at SAP.  
 
To access the portal, you will need an S-user ID, an identifier issued under SAP’s customer and partner accounts to allow access to our main support platforms, such as SAP for Me.  
 
If you're unfamiliar with S-users, we recommend checking out this detailed blog post: Learn how to get an S-user ID.  
 

Now, let’s see how you can find the SAP Cloud Availability:  

  1. Log in to me.sap.com with your S-user ID and password. 
  2. From your homepage, click on the ‘Systems & Provisioning’ dashboard at the right sidebar.  
  3. Navigate to the ‘Availability’ tab or locate the ‘Availability Status’ card from Overview tab. 
     

     


S-user ID Setup  

Ensure your S-User ID is assigned with one of the authorizations below:  

  • Display System Data.  
  • Edit System Data.  

Should you not have these permissions yet, please contact your company’s Super Administrator or use the Self-Service authorization request feature.

Finding your company’s Administrators
Locate your company’s Super, Cloud, or User Administrators via Users & Contacts . Select ‘My Important Contacts’ tab or refer to the SAP Knowledge Base Article 3222501 for more details.   

Utilizing the Self-Service Authorization Request  
Request your authorizations by going to My Authorizations and Functions. Choose the ‘Authorizations’ tab and select ‘Request Authorization’ button.  
Detailed information and screenshots can be found on document 2891528 or on SAP Blog post How to use the Self-service authorisation request.  

Exploring the SAP Cloud Availability 

Accessing SAP Cloud Availability offers you a comprehensive view of your SAP Cloud services and systems, covering both productive and non-productive environments. Key insights include: 

  • Overview of supported cloud products (Check the list of all supported products on this webpage).  
  • Current and historical cloud system status. 
  • Planned events. 
  • Latest notifications. 
  • Communicated Availability Reporting. 

When reaching the application, the first card you will see is the Availability Status.  
 
It provides you with an overview of your cloud systems’ status, quickly identifying unavailable systems or allowing you to filter for specific solutions. 
 

 

The three-dot icon on each card presents you with an explanation of the content; required authorizations; and data export option.  
 

 

 
 
Scrolling down the page, you’ll find the Events card. This view enables you to check all events affecting your cloud systems in the last 12 months. It includes planned and unplanned activities such as maintenances, major upgrades, and service disruptions, allowing you to monitor the event status, impacted data centers, and other details.  
 
The card counts with filtering options as well as expand/collapse functionality based on your preferences.  

The Availability Reporting card displays communicated availability of your cloud services and systems over the past year.    


 
All of these details can be easily monitored and managed directly within SAP for Me. However, what if you want to receive email notification about system status updates, such as system outages, planned upgrades, or service disruptions? All you need is to subscribe yourself to the SAP Cloud Notifications.  
 
Check the SAP Knowledge Base Articles 2900069 and 2896942 for reference on how to subscribe for these notifications.
 
More information about SAP Cloud Availability can be found on the following resources:  

  • Cloud Availability in SAP for Me 
  • 2548400 - Getting started with the SAP Cloud Availability - SAP for Me 
     

Who to contact for support?  

In case of issues related to SAP Cloud Availability application, please create a case with SAP for Me technical team using the Get Support feature. Make sure that you select ‘SAP for Me’ and ‘Systems & Provisioning > Availability’ under product related fields to reach the correct team.  
 

More details can be checked in 1296527 - How to create a support case for SAP Support - SAP for Me.  

Alternatively, feel free to connect with the SAP Customer Interaction Center team for initial troubleshooting or navigation guidance. Our team is available 24/7 ensuring you are covered with a “follow the sun” support and service provided in over 10 languages.  
  
Find the Customer Interaction Center official page and contact information on the following link:  Contact Customer Interaction Center   
 
 

Thank you for reading! We hope you found this helpful and would love to hear your thoughts about this blog post. Let us know what you think!   
  
Stay tuned for our upcoming Support Webinars and recorded sessions to continuously learn and get the best from SAP Support: Register Now  

 

Read more #CustomerInteractionCenter blog posts here!

entry.title: Re: How is DEPENDENTLOCATIONDEMANDMEAN calculated in IO?
entry.content:
Hi @ahmed_zeeshan73 

The key figure DEPENDENTLOCATIONDEMANDMEAN is indeed one of the more opaque standard key figures in SAP IBP, as it is not fully explained in the help portal. Let me break it down:

Here is what it represents

  • DEPENDENTLOCATIONDEMANDMEAN equals average propagated demand that a receiving location places on its supplying locations.
  • It is used as an input into the demand variability propagation logic and therefore affecting PROPAGATEDDEMANDSTDEV and ultimately Recommended Safety Stock.

Here is how it is calculated

  1. Source Definition
    • The base definition comes from SAP’s Supply Planning sample content:
    • DEPENDENTLOCATIONDEMANDMEAN =   IFNULL(LOCDEMANDADJ, 0) + IFNULL(SHIPPEDQTY, 0) + IFNULL(CUSTOMERORDERSFINALADJ, 0)

depending on which demand inputs are active in your planning area.

  1. Calculation logic
    • At location product level, IBP calculates the mean demand per period at the receiving location.
    • This mean is then propagated upstream along the supply source relationship from customer → DC → plant.
    • If there are multiple supplying sources, the demand is split according to the Source of Supply share or heuristic allocation rules.
  2. Difference vs. SAP Note 2718582
    • SAP Note 2718582 describes how dependent demand is generally derived from receiving to supplying location.
    • DEPENDENTLOCATIONDEMANDMEAN is not simply a direct copy of those equations, it is a statistical aggregation:
      • It takes actual or forecast consumption at the child node,
      • Adjusts for allocations,
      • And averages the demand over the defined horizon.
  3. Role in Safety Stock
    • This key figure’s standard deviation is used in PROPAGATEDDEMANDSTDEV.
    • Together with lead times and service levels, it influences Recommended Safety Stock in upstream nodes.

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

Inventory Optimization

What's New in SAP Integrated Business Planning for Supply Chain

entry.title: Re: Minimum Percentage Attendance for Credit = Empty or Zero
entry.content:
Hi @louis_oli4 

I made a simple test within Learning Administration: went to a class > enabled the toggle 'Automatically add to learning history as part of VLS Attendance Processing' > set the For credit and Not-for-Credit Completion Statuses and left the filed 'Minimum Percentage Attendance for Credit' empty.

When trying to save, a pop-up is displayed: "The Minimum Attendance Percentage for Credit value is required. Enter a value that is greater than 0 and less than or equal to 100."

The same error is displayed when setting 'Minimum Percentage Attendance for Credit' with the value 0 and trying to save it.

But it works when setting the value 0.10

In summary, this means the field 'Minimum Percentage Attendance for Credit' cannot be left empty and it only accepts values higher than 0 (zero).

Best regards,

entry.title: Re: Issue with Purchase Price Variance Posting in SAP ByD...
entry.content:
Hi @Gloria_Akubo,

I think the error is in the "Perpetual Cost Method" of the material master. If you set the Perpetual Cost Method as Standard in the material master, the difference between the purchase price and cost will be allocated to "differences" GL account. If you set the Perpetual Cost Method as the moving average, the purchase price is allocated against inventory account. 

 

regards,

entry.title: Re: Using data-gigya-api-link in screensets to call APIs...
entry.content:
Hi @damianomilani ,

API methods such as socialize.addConnection must be invoked through the SAP CDC JavaScript SDK, with all required parameters passed in JavaScript object. Passing parameters via HTML attributes is not supported and the SDK approach is the only officially supported method.

Also the data-gigya-api-link attribute is great for simple and declarative triggers like sending an OTP like your example or log out functionality. But for anything that requires dynamic input like choosing a social provider, passing user data then the SDK is the reliable and documented path.

Hope this is helpful

Regards,
Anand Raj

entry.title: Re: Changing materials without losing history
entry.content:
Hi @VickiG1 

Thank you for your question.

Your recycling scenario is a classic case where the chosen approach has to balance traceability such as batch genealogy and CoA with operational effort. Let me outline the main options and their implications in S/4HANA Public Cloud

First let us look at the challenge

  • Material-to-Material transfer posting. Requires Simple, low effort, it breaks traceability which means inspection results not carried forward and CoA cannot be generated with the original inspection results.
  • Secondary Process Order maintains production genealogy, new inspection lot can be created and results from the previous lot can be copied if required, provides full traceability for audit/CoA. Downside is, it requires more effort for Quality team to manage inspection lots

 

Below are the recommended Best Practice in Public Cloud

  1. Use a dedicated Grading Process Order type
    • After disassembly which is the first process order creates SFG, trigger a second process order for grading into the Finished Goods which is then the graded materials.
    • Doing it that way means, you:
      • Maintain batch classification and genealogy from original widget → SFG → FG.
      • Have a new inspection lot tied to the FG material.
      • Can configure result recording copy rules to bring forward relevant results from the SFG inspection lot into the FG inspection lot.
  2. Leverage Batch Derivation or Batch Classification
    • Activate batch derivation so that the graded FG inherits batch characteristics.
    • This ensures traceability back to the original widget batches without manual effort.
  3. Inspection Lot Handling
    • Use Usage Decision with Copy Results. The inspection lot for the FG can inherit results from the SFG lot.
    • In Public Cloud, the app Manage Usage Decisions and Record Inspection Results can be configured to pull forward results automatically.

 

What you should refrain from

  • Pure material-to-material transfer posting → You will lose genealogy and inspection traceability. This may look simple but it will not meet audit/CoA requirements in regulated or customer-facing industries.

 

Batch Management in S/4HANA Cloud

Quality Management in Production

Disassembly in Process Manufacturing (Scope Item 1F0)

 

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to understand which usage objects will be collect...
entry.content:
As outlined in KBA 3207350 - CCLM How-to-Guides, on page 17, chapter Collecting Usage:

  • "Usage can only be collected during runtime. This means, that CCLM can only record usage for runtime objects. These runtime objects do not match in all cases with the design-time objects. CCLM collects objects from TADIR which are design-time objects".

For more information, see also:

  • https://dam.sap.com/mac/app/e/pdf/preview/embed/BQWpoPm?ltr=a
  • KBA 2431632 - Object Types Whose Usage Information Can Be Analyzed in Custom Code Lifecycle Management (CCLM)

entry.title: Building Empathy into Design
entry.content:
(authored by Nicole Windmann, VP, Head of Accessible Software Development)

In today's world, where digital technology is ever-present, designing accessible software isn't just a requirement—it's a responsibility. At SAP, accessibility is not merely about checking off a list of requirements or meeting technical guidelines like those outlined in the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG). It's about creating intuitive, inclusive experiences that work for everyone, regardless of ability. By embedding accessibility early in the software development lifecycle and prioritizing user-centric design, SAP continues to lead with empathy and innovation.

A man using ASL signs "Thank you" to an unseen person on his computer screen. Text reads "1.3 billion people worldwide have a disability. 9 in 10 people with a disability acquire it through illness, injury or aging. SAP designs for all users. Stay tuned to learn more about how SAP strives for more inclusive experiences."

From Compliance to Compassion: Why Accessibility Needs a Human Lens
WCAG serve as the foundation for creating accessibility experiences. They ensure that software is technically usable by people with disabilities, but they don't always guarantee that these experiences feel intuitive, seamless, or empowering. That's where a user-centered approach makes all the difference.

Designing with empathy means listening to people who, for example, rely on assistive technologies. It means understanding that a screen reader user's experience with your app may differ greatly from that of a mouse user, and that merely focusing on color contrast doesn't account for cognitive load or task complexity, among other considerations.

At SAP, we believe accessibility should not be an afterthought. It should be integrated from the very first sketch of a user interface, and carried through research, design, development, and testing. That's why we advocate for a "shift left" in accessibility, embedding inclusive practices early in the design and development lifecycle to catch issues before they become barriers.

Introducing the Accessibility Design Tools: Empathy Meets Innovation
One of the standout achievements in SAP's accessibility journey was the publication of the Accessibility Design Tools — a new suite of resources designed to operationalize accessibility in the design process. The supporting handbook didn't just explain how to meet accessibility standards, it showcased why it matters.

From identifying potential friction points early to validating design decisions with real users, the Accessibility Design Tools, together with the Inclusive Research Handbook, are built to encourage empathy-driven decisions. They have since become a reference point for inclusive design in our enterprise software, bridging the gap between compliance and empathy.

Some Standout Features Include:

  • Accessibility Annotation Library for designs
  • Plug-ins for keyboard and screen-reading order
  • A handbook to educate on accessibility and guide through the usage of the annotations

The success of the tools demonstrated that when accessibility is framed as a shared responsibility—with resources, support, and clear guidance—innovation flourishes. It also proved that inclusive design doesn't slow teams down; it makes products stronger, more resilient, and more user-friendly for all. Whether you're a designer, developer, product manager, or advocate, you'll find practical tools, inspiring stories, and a growing community committed to building a more accessible world.

Inclusive Design is a Mindset—Not a Milestone
Accessibility is a continuous journey that requires awareness, empathy, and cross-functional collaboration. It also requires a shift in thinking: from designing for users with disabilities to creating with them.

At SAP, we're committed to keeping accessibility at the heart of our design culture. That means:

  • Prioritizing early involvement of accessibility experts in projects
  • Investing in tools for designers and developers
  • Listening to real users and valuing their lived experiences
  • Advocating for inclusive design as a core value, not an add-on

And most importantly, it means recognizing that accessibility is everyone's responsibility, not solely the job of specialists or compliance officers.

Call to Action: Stay Connected, Stay Inclusive
Since SAP first published Accessibility Design Tools, we have learned a great deal and welcomed lots of feedback. Internal and external design communities provided insight and inspiration. This feedback encouraged us to review our Accessibility Design Tools from a user-centric perspective, and we are excited that the updated Accessibility Design Tools will be available soon!

Let's think beyond compliance. Let's design with empathy. And let's make sure no one is left behind.

entry.title: Required Configuration Activityies between Development Starter and Development Development tenants
entry.content:
Hi Team!

Or if we do the Product Specific Configuration in the Dev Customizing tenant will the same setup become available in the Development Development tenant as well automatically (even if by some time delay)?

--- Support Assistant ---
Customer Experience
Configuration Activities
Configure Business Processes (3SL)


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Required Configuration Activityies between Developmen...
entry.content:
Hi Marton,

For each one of the Tenants (Development or Customizing) you can proceed with the Scoping, Organizational Setup, and Configuration (Product-Specific Configuration) separately on each Workspace created in SAP Central Business Configuration.

The Development System is where the business processes are activated, configured, and customized. These changes made in the development system are transported to the test system and further, to the Production system.

When you perform the Product-Specific Configuration in the Dev Customizing tenant (Client 100), the same configuration will not become available in the Dev Development tenant (Client 080) given that the Customizing Tenant is Client-Dependent.

In the Development System we have these 2 Main tenants (Customizing and Development) and the additional Tenant (D.120) for Parallel Line:

Development Tenant: The development tenant provides access to the SAP S/4HANA Cloud ABAP Environment. In this environment, you can build your own custom developments based on lifecycle-stable SAP objects. The development tenant is client-independent, meaning development objects built here can be accessed from the customizing tenant if permission is granted in a matter of Development. 

This is the tenant where development and extensibility activities take place and where configurations can be validated before being moved to the test tenant.

For more information about the available extensibility options, see:

  • Extensibility
  • Developer Extensibility.

Customizing Tenant: Customizing tenant / client 100 is the main workspace, used for business process configuration and key user extensibility with the SAP Fiori extensibility apps. The customizing tenant is client-dependent, meaning configurations or extensions made here can only be accessed within the customizing tenant. This is because master and transactional data is stored in database tables within a client column. Changes to business configuration in this tenant are recorded on customizing requests and are released for transport with the Export Customizing Requests Fiori app. Key user extensions built with the SAP Fiori extensibility apps in this tenant are added to software collections and released for transport with the Export Software Collections Fiori app.
This is the tenant where business configuration or system adjustments are made without development activities. Used to set up the solution according to the business needs before it is transported to test and production.

  • Configuration activities based on the reference content from SAP Central Business Configuration. For more information, see Configuration with SAP Central Business Configuration (3-System Landscape).

  • To make your configuration content available in the test and production systems, you need to transport them. For more information about transports in the 3-system landscape, see Configuration Environment in a 3-System Landscape.

  • Create low-code custom developments in key user apps. For more information, see Key User Extensibility.

Parallel Customizing Tenant: The parallel customizing tenant is part of the parallel line, which allows you to create and test configuration enhancements without affecting your main line or production system. In the parallel customizing tenant, you actively work on your parallel line content before forwarding it to the parallel test tenant for testing. For more information, see Parallel Line in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

I hope this clarifies your questions.

Please see these related and additional information:

  • System Landscapes in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition | SAP Help Portal

     

  • Configure Your Business Processes | SAP Help Portal

     

  • Key User Extensibility | SAP Help Portal

     

  • Configuration Environment in a 3-System Landscape | SAP Help Portal

     

  • Tenants in the Development System | SAP Help Portal

  • 3-System Landscape and Transport Management | SAP Help Portal

Best Regards,

Marcelo

SAP Support

I have a product that consists of three parts.
The customer can sell the complete product, for example, R100, or they can sell only the parts the customer requires: R01, R102, and R103.

Similarly, the customer can assemble product R100 using the three parts R01, R102, and R103, or they can disassemble it.

But I'm not sure it's the best practice.
I'd really appreciate your comments, please.
Thank you.

entry.title: Re: aicc wrapper report
entry.content: @Spaet, besides the information available through the Online Item Status report (KBAs 2958124 and 2165958), as it stands, it’d be required an enhancement request to specifically report on the time spent on contents containing AICC Wrapper (similar request that can be voted on). Additionally, the “TOTAL_TIME” column of the “PA_CBT_STUD_CPNT” and “PA_CBT_STUD_CPNT_MOD” tables can be queried via a custom report (KBA 2379690) to understand if it’d fulfill your business need.

entry.title: Ensuring DSCSA Compliance Readiness: How SAP Supports the Life Sciences Supply Chain
entry.content:
SAP Serialization Track & Trace Solutions for Life Sciences

 

As the pharmaceutical industry moves through the final stages of DSCSA (Drug Supply Chain Security Act) implementation, 2025 marks the decisive year. After the successful onboarding of manufacturers in May, the spotlight is now on wholesalers as they approach their August 27, 2025 enforcement deadline. The final phase will then bring dispensers (>25 FTE) into full compliance by November 27, 2025, closing the loop on DSCSA’s 10-year rollout.

With strict mandates around unit-level traceability, electronic data exchange, and real-time product verification, pharmaceutical stakeholders are increasingly turning to SAP’s serialization and traceability ecosystem to ensure compliance with confidence.

SAP's serialization solutions are used by 18 of the top 20 global pharmaceutical manufacturers, 2 of the Big 3 U.S. wholesalers, and major dispensers to enable real-time data exchange and compliance at scale. Source: Fierce Pharma 2024 revenue

Key Areas of Focus:

📅DSCSA Compliance Timelines and Stakeholder responsibility - 

✅May 27, 2025 – Manufacturers Hit Milestone

By May 27, 2025, pharmaceutical manufacturers successfully achieved:

  • Transactional Information data exchange with downstream partners
  • Full serialization and aggregation workflows
  • Real-time product verification through Verification Router Service (VRS)
  • Integration for traceability and regulatory reporting
  • Handling of suspect and illegitimate product investigations
  • Data retention and audit readiness

This demonstrated success of the 18 largest global manufacturers adoption SAP serialization has created a strong foundation that downstream partners can build upon in their journey toward DSCSA compliance. This milestone offers both a technical model and regulatory guide, enabling partners to ensure interoperability, product traceability, and compliance with FDA requirements.

📅August 27, 2025 – Wholesalers Enforcement Begins

As of August 27, 2025, wholesalers must be fully compliant with all DSCSA requirements:

  • Interoperable EPCIS 1.2 data exchange with both suppliers and customers
  • Verification of serialized product identifiers, especially for saleable returns
  • Handling of suspect and illegitimate product investigations
  • Data retention and audit readiness

This deadline marks the end of the FDA’s one-year stabilization period and phased exemption period, formalizing wholesalers obligation to support serialized traceability across the U.S. supply chain.

🕒November 27, 2025 – Dispensers Join the Compliance Chain

The final phase of DSCSA goes live on November 27, 2025, when dispensers (pharmacies, hospitals, clinics) must also begin:

  • Receiving and storing serialized EPCIS data
  • Verifying product identifiers on suspect or returned products
  • Handling of suspect and illegitimate product investigations
  • Data retention and audit readiness

While dispensers were given more time to prepare, their participation is essential to close the loop on product traceability and patient safety.

Latest updates from FDA can be found here. 

 💼 How SAP Supports DSCSA Compliance End-to-End

SAP provides a full suite of serialization and traceability tools tailored for life sciences—helping manufacturers, wholesalers, and dispensers comply at every stage.

🏷️   SAP Advanced Track and Trace for Pharmaceuticals (SAP ATTP)

A proven solution for managing serialization across packaging lines, SAP ATTP enables:

  • Serial number generation, aggregation, and disaggregation
  • Integration with ERP systems
  • Global compliance with DSCSA, including EU FMD, and others
  • Regulatory reporting and audit traceability
  • Product history and exception management
🔗 SAP Information Collaboration Hub for Life Sciences (SAP ICH)

SAP ICH powers secure, real-time data exchange between trading partners:

  • EPCIS data exchange across the supply chain
  • Verification Router Service (VRS) integration
  • Trace request and response workflows
  • Exception Management
  • Secure sharing of serialized data with trading partners
  • Ongoing support for FDA and industry interoperability guidelines

SAP ICH is essential for wholesalers and dispensers to receive, verify, and manage serialized data at scale.

✅ SAP: A Trusted Partner in DSCSA Compliance

SAP’s serialization ecosystem is trusted by leading organizations worldwide.
It is used by 18 of the top 20 global pharmaceutical manufacturers, 2 of the Big 3 U.S. wholesalers, and major dispensers to enable real-time data exchange and compliance at scale. The platform supports one of the largest networks in Life Sciences, connecting over 6,000 entities and processing an average of 1.5 million messages per month.

SAP provides:

  • 🌍Global regulatory alignment
  • 🔄End-to-end serialization and verification
  • 🧩 Secure, interoperable data exchange
  • 🛡Proven infrastructure and audit readiness
  • 📈Proven architecture for large volumes and scalability
  • 🚀Rapid partner onboarding through proprietary self-onboarding tools
  • 🔐Robust infrastructure to handle regulatory audits and trace requests
  • ⁉️Utilities for swift management of exception 
  • 📉Reduced manual efforts with automated exception handling
  • 🌍Global scalability for multi-market traceability (beyond DSCSA)

🔚 Final Thoughts

The May 27 success for manufacturers proved that industry-wide compliance is achievable. Now, with August 27 and November 27 on the horizon, the entire U.S. pharma supply chain must move in sync to fulfill the promise of the Drug Supply Chain Security Act: protecting patients through transparency, trust, and traceability.

With SAP ATTP and SAP ICH, every step of the DSCSA journey is covered from serialization to final dispense.

SAP Advanced Track and Trace for Pharmaceuticals (SAP ATTP)

SAP Information Collaboration Hub for Life Sciences (SAP ICH)

Hear directly from our customers : Bristol-Myers Squibb , Boehringer Ingelheim

entry.title: Re: Check actual cost results
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,


There are many apps to display actual costs, depending on the information you would like to retrieve. You can use app Material Inventory Values - Balance Summary / CDS View I_ML_BALANCE to check actual costs for material.

For price/activity information, check CDS View I_InventoryPriceByKeyDate and Activity Consumption Analysis for consumption of Cost Center.

There is also app Manage Material Valuations to display an overview of valuation data for your materials.

Kindly refer to the below documentation:

  • 3097384 - App/CDS Views to check actual costs - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Feature Comparison for Material Valuations and Price Changes
  • CDS Views for Management Accounting and Margin Analysis


Best Regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: 💡BTP Trial Platform SSO – Game Changer for New Customers & POCs
entry.content:
🚀🔐✨Enabling Platform SSO for SAP BTP Trial Accounts using SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS)

About Me

Hare Krishna 🙏 I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

🌟Introduction

Until recently, SAP BTP Trial accounts did not support Platform SSO. This meant that trial users had to rely on S-User IDs or SAP IDs for cockpit access, making it harder to onboard new users quickly for POCs (Proof of Concepts).

With the latest update, Platform SSO is now available for Trial accounts as well! 🎉

This is a huge enabler for:

  • New customers exploring SAP BTP for the first time.

  • Partners and developers who want to quickly set up POCs.

  • Teams that want to onboard users without waiting for an S-User.

  • Anyone looking to integrate IAS (Identity Authentication Service) or external IdPs like Azure AD, Okta, etc. for authentication.

👉In short: You can now enable SSO in your Trial just like in Enterprise accounts, which makes POCs faster, more secure, and realistic while giving new customers a smooth onboarding experience.

🌟Advantages at a Glance

  • Seamless SSO: Log in to BTP cockpit and CLI with one identity.

  • Flexible IdP Options: Use IAS or integrate with Azure AD, Okta, or other IdPs.

  • Faster POCs & Onboarding: New trial users can get started without an SAP S-user.

  • Enhanced Security: Centralized user management, MFA, and consistent policies via IAS.

  • Scalable Setup: The same trust model works when you move from trial to productive accounts.

📊Flow Diagram (Text-Based)

[User Login] 
     │
     ▼
[BTP Cockpit / CLI] ────> [Redirect to IAS] ────> [Authenticate with IAS User]
     │
     ▼
[Return to BTP Global/Subaccount] ────> [Access Cockpit / CLI with IAS Identity]
​

🔑Why Platform SSO is a Game-Changer

  1. Unified Login Experience
    Platform SSO centralizes access for all BTP platform users. Whether you use IAS or a corporate IdP (Azure AD, Okta, Ping, etc.), everyone authenticates the same way — no juggling multiple accounts.

  2. Security & Compliance
    With IAS or enterprise IdPs, you can enforce strong security controls: MFA, conditional access, SCIM provisioning, and user lifecycle policies. This significantly improves compliance posture compared to standalone trial logins.

  3. Faster POCs & Onboarding
    Before, trial accounts required S-Users which slowed down enablement. Now customers, partners, and developers can get started instantly with IAS-based trial logins. That means faster POCs, demos, and hackathon setups.

  4. Developer Productivity
    Developers can seamlessly use the same IAS login in both BTP Cockpit and BTP CLI. This avoids login confusion and makes CLI automation scripts more consistent.

  5. Future-Proof Architecture
    Platform SSO with IAS scales from trial to production. What you set up for trial POCs can be extended to full enterprise setups without redesigning your security model.

🔼High-Level Steps

  1. Enable & Activate Cloud Identity Services (IAS)
    Subscribe to IAS from your BTP global account. You’ll get an activation email to set up your tenant.

  2. Establish Trust Between BTP and IAS
    Configure trust in BTP cockpit so that IAS acts as the identity provider.

  3. Create Users
    Create a user in IAS, then create the same user in BTP cockpit against IAS IdP and assign required roles.

  4. Login via Platform SSO URL
    Access BTP cockpit using the Platform SSO URL that redirects to IAS for authentication.

  5. Verify Access in Trial Account
    Ensure the IAS user lands successfully in the trial subaccount.

  6. Extend SSO to BTP CLI
    Log in to BTP CLI using the same IAS credentials.

⚙️Step-by-Step Guide

Step 1: Create IAS Tenant (Cloud Identity Services)

  • Subscribe to SAP Cloud Identity Services (default subscription).

  • You’ll receive an activation email to set up your IAS tenant.

  • This IAS tenant will serve as the trusted IdP for BTP platform login.

🔗Example IAS Tenant:
aym6uhvub.trial-accounts.ondemand.com

Step 2: Configure Trust at Global Account Level

  1. Navigate to your Global Account in BTP Cockpit.

  2. Go to: Security → Trust Configuration → Establish Trust.

  3. Select your IAS tenant.

  4. Configure:

    • Tenant

    • Domain

    • Origin Key (unique identifier)

  5. Review & confirm.

✅Once done, IAS will appear as a Custom Identity Provider for Platform Users.

🔑Step 3: Create & Assign Users

  • First, create the user in IAS (example: btptrialiasuser@test.com).

  • Then, go to BTP cockpit → Security → Users, and create the same user against the IAS IdP you configured.

  • Finally, assign the appropriate roles/role collections (e.g., Global Account Admin, Subaccount Admin, or custom role collections).

Create user in IAS

Create user in BTP Global account

Assign User required privileges

Step 4: Login URL Creation

Use the following syntax to generate IAS login URL for cockpit access:

https://<TENANTID>.<REGION>.hana.ondemand.com/cockpit?idp=<TRUSTEDIDP>.accounts.ondemand.com
 
🔗Example (trial):
https://account.hanatrial.ondemand.com/trial?idp=aym6uhvub.trial-accounts.ondemand.com#/home/trial

👉Here, aym6uhvub is the IAS tenant identifier (highlighted).

Step 5: Authenticate with IAS

  • Open the URL → You’ll be redirected to IAS login screen.

  • Enter IAS user credentials (e.g., btptrialiasuser@test.com).

  • On successful login → Click “Go to Your Trial Account”.

✨You’re now inside the BTP Cockpit with IAS credentials (instead of S-User).

🔐Logging in with IAS via BTP CLI

Apart from cockpit login, SAP BTP CLI also supports Platform SSO with IAS.
This is especially useful for developers and administrators working with scripts, automation, or CI/CD pipelines.

Steps to Login

  1. Open your terminal.

  2. Run the following command with your IAS details and origin key:

 
btp login --idp <ORIGIN_KEY> --user <yourIASuser@example.com> --password <yourPassword>

Verify the Login

After successful login, you can test by listing your subaccounts:

btp list accounts/subaccount

 

✅This confirms that IAS-based authentication works not only in the cockpit but also with BTP CLI, making Platform SSO truly end-to-end.

❓FAQs – Platform SSO for BTP Trial

Q1: Can I use Platform SSO in a Trial account without an S-User?
A: Yes! Trial accounts now support Platform SSO via IAS or any configured Identity Provider. You no longer need an S-User for cockpit or CLI access.

Q2: Do I need to create a user in both IAS and BTP?
A: Yes. Create the user in IAS first, then create the corresponding user in BTP linked to the IAS IdP and assign the necessary roles.

Q3: Can I use Azure AD or another IdP instead of IAS?
A: Yes, any trusted Identity Provider configured at the global account level can be used for Platform SSO.

Q4: Does Platform SSO work for both cockpit and CLI?
A: Absolutely. You can log in to BTP cockpit via the SSO URL and to BTP CLI using the --idp and origin key.

Q5: Why is an origin key needed for CLI login?
A: The origin key tells the CLI which Identity Provider to use for authentication, especially when multiple IdPs are configured.

Q6: Is Platform SSO secure?
A: Yes. By using IAS or any trusted IdP, authentication is centralized, supports MFA, and follows enterprise-grade security policies.

🎯Conclusion

With Platform SSO now enabled for trial accounts, SAP has made it much easier for new customers, partners, and developers to:

  • Run POCs faster 🚀

  • Onboard trial users without S-User IDs 🔑

  • Experience enterprise-grade SSO with IAS 🔒

This change is a big step forward for customer adoption and onboarding in SAP BTP.

🙏 Thank You

A special thanks to SAP for enabling Platform SSO in Trial accounts, making it easier for new customers, partners, and developers to explore SAP BTP securely and efficiently.
This update truly accelerates POCs, onboarding, and hands-on learning for everyone.

entry.title: How to find the line items that made up settlement? This may help.
entry.content:
I could be missing some obvious table or logic but for years I have found it impossible to find the source line items that made up the totals in a settlement document.  I searched high and low and I could never find SAP's logic.  So I decided to take a kick at it using HANA SQL.  Please be gentle in your responses as I am sure there is a better way, better sql, etc.

The problem I needed to solve is to be able to find Orders line items that settled to Projects and here is how I did it.

 

 
 /********* Begin Procedure Script ************/ 
 BEGIN 
 	 var_out = WITH BASE_DATA
AS (
	SELECT T1."MANDT" AS "CLIENT"
		,T1."LEDNR" AS "LEDGER"
		,T1."VERSN" AS "VERSION"
		,T1."KOKRS" AS "CONTROLLINGAREA"
		,T1."BUKRS" AS "COMPANYCODE"
		,T1."GSBER" AS "BUSINESSAREA"
		,T1."OBJNR" AS "OBJECTNUMBER"
		,T1."ACCASTY" AS "OBJECTTYPE"
		,T1."BELNR" AS "DOCUMENTNUMBER"
		,T1."BLTXT" AS "DOCHEADERTEXT"
		,T1."SGTXT" AS "SEGMENTTEXT"
		,T1."ZLENR" AS "DOCITEMNUMBER"
		,T1."BUZEI" AS "POSTINGROW"
		,T1."GJAHR" AS "FISCALYEAR"
		,T1."PERIO" AS "PERIOD"
		,T1."BUDAT" AS "POSTINGDATE_S"
		,TO_DATE(NULLIF(T1."BUDAT", '00000000'), 'YYYYMMDD') AS "POSTINGDATE_E"		
		,T1."BLDAT" AS "DOCUMENTDATE_S"
		,TO_DATE(NULLIF(T1."BLDAT", '00000000'), 'YYYYMMDD') AS "DOCUMENTDATE_E"		
		,T1."CPUDT" AS "DATECREATED_S"
		,TO_DATE(NULLIF(T1."CPUDT", '00000000'), 'YYYYMMDD') AS "DATECREATED_E"		
		,T1."CPUTM" AS "TIMECREATED_S"
		,TO_TIME(NULLIF(T1."CPUTM", '000000'), 'HHMISS') AS "TIMECREATED_E"
		,UTCTOLOCAL(ADD_SECONDS(TO_DATE('1990-01-01', 'YYYY-MM-DD'), CAST((CAST(T1."TIMESTMP" / 10000 AS INT)) AS INT)), 'PST') AS "DATETIMECREATED"
		,T1."KSTAR" AS "COSTELEMENT"
		,T1."HRKFT" AS "COSUBKEY"
		,T1."WKGBTR" AS "TOTALCACUR"
		,T1."WKFBTR" AS "FIXEDVALUECACUR"
		,T1."KWAER" AS "CACURRENCY"
		,T1."MEGBTR" AS "TOTALQUANTITY"
		,T1."MEFBTR" AS "FIXEDQUANTITY"
		,T1."MEINH" AS "UNITOFMEASURE"
		,T1."VRGNG" AS "BUSTRANSACTION"
		,T1."WRTTP" AS "VALUETYPE"
		,T1."BEKNZ" AS "DEBITCREDIT"
		,T1."REFBN" AS "REFDOCUMENTNO"
		,COALESCE(LPAD(T2."ABRNR", 10, '0'), '') AS "SETTLEMENTSEQUENCE"
		,COALESCE(T2."GJAHR", '') AS "SETTLEMENTYEAR"
		,COALESCE(T2."PERIO", '') AS "SETTLEMENTPERIOD"
		,COALESCE(T2."STBEL", '') AS "DOCUMENTREVERSED"
		,COALESCE(T1."STOKZ", '') AS "REVERSED"
		,COALESCE(T1."STFLG", '') AS "REVERSALDOC"
		,T1."AWTYP" AS "REFPROCEDURE"
		,T3."PSPEL" AS "WBSELEMENTID"
		,T4."OBJNR" AS "WBSELEMENTOBJECT"
		,T4."POSKI" AS "WBSELEMENTSHORTID"
		,T1."EBELN" AS "PURCHASINGDOC"
		,T1."EBELP" AS "PURCHASINGDOCITEM"
		,T1."PERNR" AS "PERSONNELNUMBER"
		,T1."PAROB" AS "PARTNEROBJECT"
		,T1."MATNR" AS "MATERIALNUMBER"
		,T1."WERKS" AS "PLANT"
		,T1."GKONT" AS "OFFSETACCTNO"
		,T1."GKOAR" AS "OFFSETACCTTYPE"
	FROM "V_COVP" AS T1
	LEFT JOIN "AUAK" AS T2
		ON T1."MANDT" = T2."MANDT" AND T1."REFBN" = T2."BELNR"
	INNER JOIN "AUFK" AS T3
		ON T1."MANDT" = T3."MANDT" AND T1."OBJNR" = T3."OBJNR" AND T3."PSPEL" <> '00000000' AND (T3."AUTYP" IN ( '01' , '06' , '30' ))
	INNER JOIN "PRPS" AS T4
		ON T3."MANDT" = T4."MANDT" AND T3."PSPEL" = T4."PSPNR"
	WHERE T1."MANDT" = SESSION_CONTEXT('CLIENT') AND T1."ACCASTY" = 'OR' AND T1."GJAHR" BETWEEN :P_FISCAL_YEAR_FROM AND :P_FISCAL_YEAR_TO
	)
	,SORTED_DATA
AS (
	SELECT *
		,ROW_NUMBER() OVER (
			PARTITION BY "OBJECTNUMBER" ORDER BY "FISCALYEAR"
				,"PERIOD"
				,"DATECREATED_S"
				,"TIMECREATED_S"
				,"DOCITEMNUMBER"
			) AS "ROWNUMBER"
	FROM BASE_DATA
	ORDER BY "OBJECTNUMBER"
		,"FISCALYEAR"
		,"PERIOD"
		,"DATETIMECREATED"
		,"DOCITEMNUMBER"
	)
	,MATCHED_DATA
AS (
	SELECT T1.*
		,COALESCE((
				SELECT FIRST_VALUE("REFDOCUMENTNO" ORDER BY "ROWNUMBER")
				FROM SORTED_DATA AS T2
				WHERE T2."OBJECTNUMBER" = T1."OBJECTNUMBER" AND T2."DEBITCREDIT" = 'A' AND T2."ROWNUMBER" > T1."ROWNUMBER" AND T2."COSTELEMENT" = T1."COSTELEMENT" AND T2."REVERSED" = '' AND T2."REVERSALDOC" = '' AND T1."DEBITCREDIT" <> 'A'
				), '') AS "SETTLEMENTDOCUMENT"
        ,COALESCE((
				SELECT FIRST_VALUE("POSTINGDATE_S" ORDER BY "ROWNUMBER")
				FROM SORTED_DATA AS T2
				WHERE T2."OBJECTNUMBER" = T1."OBJECTNUMBER" AND T2."DEBITCREDIT" = 'A' AND T2."ROWNUMBER" > T1."ROWNUMBER" AND T2."COSTELEMENT" = T1."COSTELEMENT" AND T2."REVERSED" = '' AND T2."REVERSALDOC" = '' AND T1."DEBITCREDIT" <> 'A'
				), '') AS "SETTLEMENTDATE_S"				
        ,COALESCE((
				SELECT FIRST_VALUE("DOCUMENTNUMBER" ORDER BY "ROWNUMBER")
				FROM SORTED_DATA AS T2
				WHERE T2."OBJECTNUMBER" = T1."OBJECTNUMBER" AND T2."DEBITCREDIT" = 'A' AND T2."ROWNUMBER" > T1."ROWNUMBER" AND T2."COSTELEMENT" = T1."COSTELEMENT" AND T2."REVERSED" = '' AND T2."REVERSALDOC" = '' AND T1."DEBITCREDIT" <> 'A'
				), '') AS "PRDOCUMENTNUMBER"				
	FROM SORTED_DATA T1
	ORDER BY T1."OBJECTNUMBER"
		,T1."ROWNUMBER"
	)
	,FINAL_DATA
AS (
	SELECT T1."CLIENT"
		,T1."LEDGER"
		,T2."DDTEXT" AS "LEDGERTEXT"
		,T1."VERSION"
		,T3.TXT AS "VERSIONTEXT"
		,T1."CONTROLLINGAREA"
		,T4."BEZEI" AS "CONTROLLINGAREATEXT"
		,T4."KTOPL" AS "CHARTOFACCOUNTS"
		,T18."KTPLT" AS "CHARTOFACCOUNTSTEXT"
		,T1."COMPANYCODE"
		,T19."BUTXT" AS "COMPANYCODETEXT"
		,T1."BUSINESSAREA"
		,T20."GTEXT" AS "BUSINESSAREATEXT"
		,T1."OBJECTNUMBER"
		,T1."OBJECTTYPE"
		,T5."OBART_LD" AS "OBJECTTYPE_EN"
		,CASE WHEN T5."TXT60" != '' THEN "TXT60" WHEN T5."TXT20" != '' THEN "TXT20" WHEN T5."TXT15" != '' THEN "TXT15" ELSE T5."TXT10" END AS "OBJECTTYPETEXT"
		,T1."DOCUMENTNUMBER"
		,T1."DOCHEADERTEXT"
		,T1."SEGMENTTEXT"
		,T1."DOCITEMNUMBER"
		,T1."POSTINGROW"
		,T1."FISCALYEAR"
		,T1."PERIOD"
		,T1."POSTINGDATE_S"
		,T1."POSTINGDATE_E"
		,T1."DOCUMENTDATE_S"
		,T1."DOCUMENTDATE_E"		
		,T1."DATECREATED_S"
		,T1."DATECREATED_E"		
		,T1."TIMECREATED_S"
		,T1."TIMECREATED_E"		
		,T1."DATETIMECREATED"
		,T1."COSTELEMENT"
		,T7."LTEXT" AS "COSTELEMENTTEXT"
		,T1."COSUBKEY"
		,T1."TOTALCACUR"
		,T1."FIXEDVALUECACUR"
		,T1."CACURRENCY"
		,T6."KTEXT" AS "CACURRENCYTEXT"
		,T1."TOTALQUANTITY"
		,T1."FIXEDQUANTITY"
		,T1."UNITOFMEASURE"
		,T8."MSEH3" AS "UNITOFMEASSUREENG"
		,T8."MSEHT" AS "UNITOFMEASSURETEXT"
		,T1."BUSTRANSACTION"
		,T11."TXT" AS "BUSTRANSACTIONTEXT"
		,T1."VALUETYPE"
		,T9."DDTEXT" AS "VALUETYPETEXT"
		,T1."DEBITCREDIT"
		,T10."BEKNZ_LD" AS "DEBITCREDIT_EN"
		,T10."DDTEXT" AS "DEBITCREDITTEXT"
		,T1."REFDOCUMENTNO"
		,T1."SETTLEMENTSEQUENCE"
		,T1."SETTLEMENTYEAR"
		,T1."SETTLEMENTPERIOD"
		,T1."DOCUMENTREVERSED"
		,T1."REVERSED"
		,T1."REVERSALDOC"
		,T1."SETTLEMENTDOCUMENT"
		,T1."SETTLEMENTDATE_S"
		,TO_DATE(NULLIF(T1."SETTLEMENTDATE_S", '00000000'), 'YYYYMMDD') AS "SETTLEMENTDATE_E"	
		,T1."PRDOCUMENTNUMBER"	
		,T1."REFPROCEDURE"
		,T12."OTEXT" AS "REFPROCEDURETEXT"
		,T1."WBSELEMENTID"
		,T1."WBSELEMENTOBJECT"
		,T1."WBSELEMENTSHORTID"
		,T1."PURCHASINGDOC"
		,T1."PURCHASINGDOCITEM"
		,T13."TXZ01" AS "PURCHASINGDOCITEMTEXT"
		,T13."LIFNR" AS "SUPPLIER"
		,TRIM(T21."NAME1" || ' ' || T21."NAME2") AS "SUPPLIERNAME"
		,T1."PERSONNELNUMBER"
		,T14."ENAME" AS "EMPLOYEENAME"
		,T1."PARTNEROBJECT"
		,T1."MATERIALNUMBER"
		,T15."MAKTX" AS "MATERIALTEXT"
		,T1."PLANT"
		,T17."NAME1" AS "PLANTTEXT"
		,T1."OFFSETACCTNO"
		,T1."OFFSETACCTTYPE"
		,T16."DDTEXT" AS "OFFSETACCTTYPETEXT"
		,T1."ROWNUMBER"
	FROM MATCHED_DATA AS T1
	INNER JOIN "DD07T" AS T2
		ON T1."LEDGER" = T2."DOMVALUE_L" AND T2."DOMNAME" = 'LEDNR' AND T2."DDLANGUAGE" = 'E' AND T2."AS4LOCAL" = 'A'
	INNER JOIN "TKT09" AS T3
		ON T1."CLIENT" = T3."MANDT" AND T1."CONTROLLINGAREA" = T3."KOKRS" AND T1."VERSION" = T3."VERSN" AND T3."LANGU" = 'E'
	INNER JOIN "TKA01" AS T4
		ON T1."CLIENT" = T4."MANDT" AND T1."CONTROLLINGAREA" = T4."KOKRS"
	INNER JOIN "TBO01" AS T5
		ON T1."OBJECTTYPE" = T5."OBART" AND T5."SPRAS" = 'E'
	INNER JOIN "TCURT" AS T6
		ON T1."CLIENT" = T6."MANDT" AND T1."CACURRENCY" = T6."WAERS" AND T6."SPRAS" = 'E'
	INNER JOIN "CSKU" AS T7
		ON T1."CLIENT" = T7."MANDT" AND T4."KTOPL" = T7."KTOPL" AND T1."COSTELEMENT" = T7."KSTAR" AND T7."SPRAS" = 'E'
	LEFT JOIN "T006A" AS T8
		ON T1."CLIENT" = T8."MANDT" AND T1."UNITOFMEASURE" = T8."MSEHI" AND T8."SPRAS" = 'E'
	INNER JOIN "DD07T" AS T9
		ON T1."VALUETYPE" = T9."DOMVALUE_L" AND T9."DOMNAME" = 'CO_WRTTP' AND T9."DDLANGUAGE" = 'E' AND T9."AS4LOCAL" = 'A'
	INNER JOIN (
		SELECT "DD07T"."DOMVALUE_L"
			,"DD07T"."DDTEXT"
			,"TKABE"."BEKNZ_LD"
		FROM "DD07T"
		INNER JOIN "TKABE"
			ON "DD07T"."DOMVALUE_L" = "TKABE"."BEKNZ" AND "TKABE"."SPRAS" = 'E'
		WHERE "DD07T"."DOMNAME" = 'BEKNZ' AND "DD07T"."DDLANGUAGE" = 'E' AND "DD07T"."AS4LOCAL" = 'A'
		) AS T10
		ON T1."DEBITCREDIT" = T10."DOMVALUE_L"
	INNER JOIN "TJ01T" AS T11
		ON T1."BUSTRANSACTION" = T11."VRGNG" AND T11."SPRAS" = 'E'
	INNER JOIN "TTYPT" AS T12
		ON T1."REFPROCEDURE" = T12."AWTYP" AND T12."SPRAS" = 'E'
	LEFT JOIN (
		SELECT "EKKO"."MANDT"
			,"EKKO"."EBELN"
			,"EKKO"."BUKRS"
			,"EKKO"."LIFNR"
			,"EKPO"."EBELP"
			,"EKPO"."TXZ01"
		FROM "EKKO"
		INNER JOIN "EKPO"
			ON "EKKO"."MANDT" = "EKPO"."MANDT" AND "EKKO"."EBELN" = "EKPO"."EBELN"
		) AS T13
		ON T1."CLIENT" = T13."MANDT" AND T1."PURCHASINGDOC" = T13."EBELN" AND T1."PURCHASINGDOCITEM" = T13."EBELP"
	LEFT JOIN "PA0001" T14
		ON T1."CLIENT" = T14."MANDT" AND T1."PERSONNELNUMBER" = T14."PERNR" AND TO_NVARCHAR(CURRENT_DATE, 'YYYYMMDD') BETWEEN T14."BEGDA"
				AND T14."ENDDA"
	LEFT JOIN "MAKT" T15
		ON T1."CLIENT" = T15."MANDT" AND T1."MATERIALNUMBER" = T15."MATNR" AND T15."SPRAS" = 'E'
	LEFT JOIN "DD07T" AS T16
		ON T1."OFFSETACCTTYPE" = T16."DOMVALUE_L" AND T16."DOMNAME" = 'KOART' AND T16."DDLANGUAGE" = 'E' AND T16."AS4LOCAL" = 'A'
	LEFT JOIN "T001W" T17
		ON T1."CLIENT" = T17."MANDT" AND T1."PLANT" = T17."WERKS"
	INNER JOIN "T004T" T18
		ON T4."MANDT" = T18."MANDT" AND T4."KTOPL" = T18."KTOPL" AND T18."SPRAS" = 'E'
	INNER JOIN "T001" T19
		ON T1."CLIENT" = T19."MANDT" AND T1."COMPANYCODE" = T19."BUKRS"
	INNER JOIN "TGSBT" T20
		ON T1."CLIENT" = T20."MANDT" AND T1."BUSINESSAREA" = T20."GSBER" AND T20."SPRAS" = 'E'
	LEFT JOIN "LFA1" T21
		ON T13."MANDT" = T21."MANDT" AND T13."LIFNR" = T21."LIFNR"
	)
SELECT *
FROM FINAL_DATA;

 	 

END /********* End Procedure Script ************/

 

The key was to sort the records  by  "OBJECTNUMBER" ,"FISCALYEAR" ,"PERIOD" ,"DATETIMECREATED" ,"DOCITEMNUMBER" and assign a row number to each record to get the order I needed.

 

	,SORTED_DATA
AS (
	SELECT *
		,ROW_NUMBER() OVER (
			PARTITION BY "OBJECTNUMBER" ORDER BY "FISCALYEAR"
				,"PERIOD"
				,"DATECREATED_S"
				,"TIMECREATED_S"
				,"DOCITEMNUMBER"
			) AS "ROWNUMBER"
	FROM BASE_DATA
	ORDER BY "OBJECTNUMBER"
		,"FISCALYEAR"
		,"PERIOD"
		,"DATETIMECREATED"
		,"DOCITEMNUMBER"
	)

 

The next step was to get the next settlement document immediately following.  This is where the Row Number comes in.

 

	,MATCHED_DATA
AS (
	SELECT T1.*
		,COALESCE((
				SELECT FIRST_VALUE("REFDOCUMENTNO" ORDER BY "ROWNUMBER")
				FROM SORTED_DATA AS T2
				WHERE T2."OBJECTNUMBER" = T1."OBJECTNUMBER" AND T2."DEBITCREDIT" = 'A' AND T2."ROWNUMBER" > T1."ROWNUMBER" AND T2."COSTELEMENT" = T1."COSTELEMENT" AND T2."REVERSED" = '' AND T2."REVERSALDOC" = '' AND T1."DEBITCREDIT" <> 'A'
				), '') AS "SETTLEMENTDOCUMENT"
        ,COALESCE((
				SELECT FIRST_VALUE("POSTINGDATE_S" ORDER BY "ROWNUMBER")
				FROM SORTED_DATA AS T2
				WHERE T2."OBJECTNUMBER" = T1."OBJECTNUMBER" AND T2."DEBITCREDIT" = 'A' AND T2."ROWNUMBER" > T1."ROWNUMBER" AND T2."COSTELEMENT" = T1."COSTELEMENT" AND T2."REVERSED" = '' AND T2."REVERSALDOC" = '' AND T1."DEBITCREDIT" <> 'A'
				), '') AS "SETTLEMENTDATE_S"				
        ,COALESCE((
				SELECT FIRST_VALUE("DOCUMENTNUMBER" ORDER BY "ROWNUMBER")
				FROM SORTED_DATA AS T2
				WHERE T2."OBJECTNUMBER" = T1."OBJECTNUMBER" AND T2."DEBITCREDIT" = 'A' AND T2."ROWNUMBER" > T1."ROWNUMBER" AND T2."COSTELEMENT" = T1."COSTELEMENT" AND T2."REVERSED" = '' AND T2."REVERSALDOC" = '' AND T1."DEBITCREDIT" <> 'A'
				), '') AS "PRDOCUMENTNUMBER"				
	FROM SORTED_DATA T1
	ORDER BY T1."OBJECTNUMBER"
		,T1."ROWNUMBER"
	)

 

Now you may need to add addition filter criteria because we have only one Controlling Area, etc.
To adjust the totals to meet the distribution rules just join the results to COBRB and apply the appropriate logic.  ie. percentage if percentage then do it to three decimals because SAP has some strange logic for that which I can't figure out.  Anyone know the logic please let me know.

Filter out Debit/Credit = 'A' to remove settlement from the result.

Looking for feedback as well.

entry.title: Re: Production process
entry.content:
Hello @AngelT 

Yes, run Rework Processing, Stock-Manufactured Material (BJN). That’s the correct Best Practice script for reworking finished stock already in inventory.

Conversion order is NOT a Rework order. In SAP, conversion usually means converting a planned order to a production order standard MRP step, not a rework scenario. There isn’t a Best Practice script called “Conversion order.” If you meant rework, use BJN (for stock) or BJQ for rework of work-in-process.

BJN/BJQ scope items listed in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition manufacturing scope overview.

Convert Planned Orders app what conversion means. SAP Fiori Apps Library

If your case involves reworking goods that have already been Goods Received (GR’d) into stock, please contact BJN. If reworking occurs within an open order before the Goods Receipt (GR), use BJQ.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Automate PFCG process
entry.content:
I suspect you are trying to avoid this class somehow because you are not able to create an object using `CREATE OBJECT` or `NEW` as this class has a "private constructor" (create private as part of the class declaration)

That means that only the class itself can create objects of its type. That is the well-known Factory class pattern.

In this case the method which allows you get a new instance of this class is `RETRIEVE_FOR_UPDATE`.

Basically call this method beforehand and grab the `ER_ROLE` parameter inside a reference. Then you use this reference to call `MENU_ADD_TRANSACTION`

entry.title: Re: RRB Billing by Activity Type (Consultant Roles) and Q...
entry.content:
When configuring RRB the primary action is to set up the Dynamic Item Processor (DIP), this is the billing engine that is used for quoting and invoicing.

Refer to SAP Note- 301117 - "Enhanced documentation for dynamic item processor (DIP)" which is extremely helpful.

The summarized quote and invoice is all determined by how you set up the DIP.  The summarization you require is standard RRB.

You are correct, during normal invoicing the Sales Order Line Item is a "dummy" line that just contains the DIP Profile.  For Quote creation the DIP is specified on the PS project.

Through the DIP you can set up the creation of a Sales Quotation from the planned quantities and values on the PS Project. 

For either quoting or invoicing the Output Form is determined via standard SD configuration and master data.

entry.title: Re: How to integrate SAP GRDC with Datasphere for public...
entry.content:
Hello Ahmed,

Good questions. These fields in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition vary depending on whether the communication system is for inbound S/4 receiving calls or outbound S/4 initiating calls to another system.

Host field (Communication System):

  • Enter the URL of the target system (excluding /sap/...).
    • When making an outbound call to SAP BTP or another external system, use the service endpoint URL given by that system.
    • For inbound calls, such as when another system accesses S/4, it’s best to leave it blank since the S/4HANA Cloud host is automatically determined.

Outbound User:

  • This is the technical user that S/4 will use when making outbound calls.
  • If you have created a Communication User (using Maintain Communication Users) with a password or certificate, enter that user ID here.
  • Assign the inbound caller to the user specified in the Communication Arrangement.

Path field (Communication Arrangement → Outbound Services):

  • By default, leave it as /.
  • Only modify this if the external system specifies a particular relative path after the host, such as /api/v1/data.
  • In most standard scenarios, such as SAP-delivered communication cases, / is correct, and the system automatically adds the proper service path.

Briefly

  • Host = endpoint base URL of the external system (if outbound).
  • Outbound User = your technical communication user created in S/4.
  • Path = normally just “/” unless the documentation of the external API says otherwise.

Check below references

SAP Help -How to Create Communication Systems

SAP Help-Communication Arrangements

Let me know if you need any support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: SAP Enable Now - Document template generated output
entry.content:
Hi Melissa,

It is likely that one of three issues is causing your problem:

1. You have applied manual formatting to the text that is not appearing correctly when generated as documentation.  If you have applied manual formatting to text in Enable Now, even if you have also applied a text style, the manual formatting is carried over into the documentation.  To remove the manual formatting, open the text in Producer that is not generating correct, select the text and click the following button


2. You have applied the incorrect text style to the text that is not formatted correctly.  So, open the text in Producer and apply the correct text style to the text

3. When you define a set of Documentation Settings - Resources > Documentation Settings - in Producer, you specify the Text Styles object that is to apply to the documentation when it is generated.  Information like font size is defined in that Text Styles object.  After generating the documentation, click on the text that is not formatted the way that you would like and check the text style that has been applied to the text.  Then check the Text Styles object in Producer - Resources > Adaptable Resources > ... - to determine the formatting that should be applied to the text. 

It may be necessary to duplicate the existing Text Styles object in Resources > Adaptable Resources to create a new object and then apply different styling to the text styles in that object.  You can then apply the new Text Styles object to the Documentation Settings object to ensure that the text is generated with the correct text styles.

Regards
Shane

entry.title: Re: Automatic Purchase Requisition to Purchase order- W/O...
entry.content:
Hello @SB1184 

Great follow-up questions!

Info Record vs. Service Condition Record

    • The Service Info Record in S/4HANA Cloud primarily establishes the link between vendor and service category/material group. The mandatory price field in the Info Record is merely a reference value, not used for detailed pricing
    • The Service Condition Record is where you store the pricing logic, whether it's per service, material group, or text item. This is what the system references during purchase order and service entry sheet processing.

An Info Record serves as a link or reference, while a Condition Record reflects the actual pricing.

Automatic Source Determination in PR

In the Public Cloud, you cannot maintain a manual Source List. Instead, the source of supply is determined automatically from:

      • Contract/Outline Agreement (if one exists for that material/service group & vendor), or
      • Service Info Record (vendor assignment), or
      • Approved Supplier Lists (if enabled).

If none is found, the PR stays without a source, and you assign it manually.

Reference: SAP Learning- Service Purchasing in S/4HANA Cloud

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: How can I customize repetitive translations for book...
entry.content:
Hi,

There is no way to modify the way that Translation Hub translates Enable Now content on the Enable Now side.  If this is possible, and I'm not sure that it is, the change would need to be made on the Translation Hub side.  The issue with this is that you are unlikely to be using your own Translation Hub licenses when translating content using Enable Now.  Therefore, even if it were possible to modify Translation Hub to change the way that it translates individual words, when the request is sent by Enable Now to Translation Hub, it would not know that it was to use your customizations.  If it is possible to customize the way that Translation Hub translates individual words, it would be necessary to use your Translation Hub license details.  To specify your license details in Enable Now, open Administration > Server Settings in Manager, and enter your license details in the Features > Machine Translation section of settings.

Regards
Shane
